topic.name: Wisdom Literature
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Wisdom Literature in Bible & Theology

objectives.objective_text: Identify that there is a time for everything.
Name the 'Preacher' who looked for happiness.
Identify Job as a man who loved God but suffered.
Name God as the one who is in charge of everything.
Identify Proverbs as a book of wise sayings.
Name Solomon as the wisest king.
Identify Psalms as songs to God.
Name David as a writer of songs.
Identify this book as a song about love.
Name marriage as a special gift from God.
Recall that only God can make us truly happy.
Observe that toys break and don't last forever.
Recall that Job did not stop loving God even when sad.
Observe that God made the Behemoth and Leviathan.
Recall that listening to parents is wise.
Observe the difference between a wise child and a foolish one.
Recall 'The Lord is my Shepherd'.
Observe that we can sing when happy or sad.
Recall that God loves His people very much.
Observe that husband and wife are best friends.
Produce a reflection on finding joy in the simple gifts of God.
Summarize the theme: The Fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom.
Summarize the search for meaning in pleasure, work, and wisdom.
Explain the phrase 'Meaningless' or 'Vanity'.
Explain the difference between fleeting joy and eternal purpose.
Defend the book's presence in the canon as essential realism.
Summarize the test of Job (losing family and health).
Explain that bad things happen even to good people.
Explain the limit of Satan's power.
Defend the sovereignty of God in suffering.
Explain the difference between knowledge and wisdom.
Explain the warning against the 'Strange Woman' (Folly).
Defend the practical value of Proverbs for modern ethics.
Summarize the different types of Psalms (Praise, Thanksgiving, Lament).
Explain how to use Psalms for prayer.
Explain the use of Selah and other musical terms.
Defend the use of Psalms in corporate worship.
Produce a study on the Kingship of Yahweh in the Psalms.
Summarize it as a poem about a bride and groom.
Explain that marriage is between a man and a woman.
Explain the 'shulammite' woman.
Defend the holiness of physical intimacy within marriage.
Compare life 'under the sun' with life with God.
Apply the conclusion: Fear God and keep His commandments.
Analyze the reality of death and injustice in the book.
Interpret the call to remember the Creator in youth.
Connect Ecclesiastes to the dissatisfaction of materialism.
Compare Job's patience with his friends' bad advice.
Apply the truth that we should trust God even when we don't understand.
Analyze the dialogue between Job and his three friends.
Interpret God's answer from the whirlwind.
Connect the book to the problem of evil (Theodicy).
Compare the sluggard (lazy person) with the ant.
Apply proverbs about words and anger to daily life.
Analyze the structure: Father's instruction vs. Woman Wisdom.
Interpret the nature of a proverb (general truth, not absolute promise).
Connect wisdom to the order of creation.
Compare Psalm 1 (The Righteous) and Psalm 2 (The Messiah).
Apply a Psalm to your own feelings.
Analyze the structure of Hebrew poetry (Parallelism).
Interpret the Messianic Psalms (e.g., 22, 110).
Connect the five books of Psalms to the Torah.
Compare the love in the book to God's love for the church.
Apply the idea of loyalty in relationships.
Analyze the poetic language of love and devotion.
Interpret the book as a celebration of marital intimacy.
Connect the marriage covenant to the biblical view of sexuality.
Evaluate the authorship debate (Solomon vs. later sage).
Evaluate the role of Elihu.
Evaluate the personification of Wisdom in chapter 8.
Evaluate the imprecatory Psalms (prayers for judgment).
Evaluate the biblical view of sexuality vs. cultural views.
Construct a philosophical apologetic using Ecclesiastes.
Construct a summary of the retribution principle and how Job refutes it.
Synthesize Job as a type of the righteous sufferer (Christ).
Construct a topical study of Proverbs (money, speech, friendship).
Synthesize the 'Proverbs 31 Woman' as an ideal of wisdom.
Construct a comparison of literal vs. allegorical interpretations.
Synthesize the Song with the 'Bride of Christ' imagery in the NT.
Construct a theology of the emotions based on the Psalms.
